comment.author: 11516254@N00
comment._content: The London Stereoscopic Company was founded in 1854 by George S. Nottage. As well as producing photographs, the company acted as a retailer for photographic equipment. The firm was successful in all branches of photography. From 1860 to 1862 the company was based at 54 Cheapside, London. From 1860 to 1861 it also had premise at 313 Oxford Street. In 1863 the company occupied 54 Cheapside and 110 Regent Street. From 1864 onwards it occupied a variety of locations on Cheapside, Regent Street and Bow Churchyard. The company was known by several slightly different names. In 1863 it is referred to as the London Stereoscopic and Photographic Co. and C. de V. Institute. From 1864 it was known as the London Stereoscopic and Photographic Co. Ltd.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: This is probably Regent Street. Looking at the high-res image, I think the street name at upper right may be Glasshouse, which is off Regent Street. And at the bottom left, near street level is "108", According to 82.109.94.204/photolondon/pages/details.asp?pid=1249 the address for London Stereoscopic & Photographic Co was 106 & 108 Regent Street, Westminster from July 15 1890 - September 1922

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Brian May (of the rock group Queen) and Elena Vidal " are seeking to recreate the magic of the company" and have just launched londonstereo.com/ It includes pictures of the store (without the damage) on londonstereo.com/introduction.html

comment.author: 52312156@N00
comment._content:
London Stereoscopic & Photographic Company (floruit 1854-1908)
Artist associated with 407 portraits
The London Stereoscopic Company was founded in 1854 by George S. Nottage, and was still in business in 1908. It was successful in all branches of photography, but specialised in the mass production of stereoscopic photographs. The firm's output was vast; there were over 100,000 stereo photographs listed in its 1858 catalogue. The company was known by several slightly different names. In 1863 it is referred to as the London Stereoscopic and Photographic Co. and C. de V. Institute. From 1864 it was known as the London Stereoscopic and Photographic Co. Ltd. The firm occupied a variety of premises on Oxford Street, Regent Street, Cheapside and Bow Churchyard. Its archive is now held by Getty Images.
